headline: Security Best Practices You Should Know

digest_items.title: Implement data classification
digest_items.why: Classification ensures appropriate security controls for sensitive data
digest_items.fix: Label data as public, internal, confidential, or restricted

digest_items.title: Disable directory listing
digest_items.why: Directory listing exposes file structure and sensitive files
digest_items.fix: Set 'Options -Indexes' in Apache or 'autoindex off' in nginx

digest_items.title: Implement security awareness training
digest_items.why: Human error is the leading cause of security incidents
digest_items.fix: Conduct quarterly phishing simulations and security training

digest_items.title: Implement API authentication
digest_items.why: Unauthenticated APIs allow unauthorized access to data and functions
digest_items.fix: Use OAuth 2.0, JWT tokens, or API keys with proper validation

digest_items.title: Use secure random number generation
digest_items.fix: Use crypto.randomBytes() or secrets module, not Math.random()

digest_items.title: Scan for exposed secrets in repos
digest_items.why: Committed secrets can be found by attackers scanning public repositories
digest_items.fix: Use tools like git-secrets or truffleHog to scan commit history

digest_items.title: Use parameterized queries
digest_items.why: Parameterized queries prevent SQL injection attacks
digest_items.fix: Never concatenate user input into SQL; use prepared statements instead

digest_items.title: Verify API versioning strategy
digest_items.why: Deprecated API versions may have unpatched vulnerabilities
digest_items.fix: Maintain clear deprecation timeline and force upgrades for old versions
